Building and Evaluating Ethical Robotic Systems
IROS 2021 Workshop
October 1st • 16:00 - 18:00 CEST

Autonomous systems already have a large impact on society, both for individuals and institutions, and the role they play is expected to increase. For example, many industries including transportation, surveillance systems, voice assistants, smart home technology, power grid management, military technology, eldercare, and resource extraction all either currently rely on autonomous embodied systems or plan to in the future. However, our ability to integrate autonomous systems into our lives has outstripped our ability to design and build autonomous systems whose behavior is reliably ethical. There are many fundamental gaps in our understanding of how such systems might be constructed and how they should be integrated within society. These include questions about the impact of autonomous systems on society, engineering questions regarding design, implementation, and evaluation, and questions involving regulation for robotics and methods for analyzing the ethical implications of robots. Together, these questions represent a significant obstacle to achieving reliably ethical robots.

In answering these questions, this workshop has four objectives. First, by offering a venue to submit and present research, it promotes further research on these topics, with the goal of working towards a more comprehensive model of how to build ethical robotic systems. Second, by elevating the importance of questions about affordable, scalable, and reproducible experimental evaluation, this workshop promotes discussion and collaboration on the next generation of evaluation techniques for embodied ethical agents. Much of the existing work on ethical AI approaches the topic from either a theoretical perspective or uses simulations that, though illustrative, do not compare meaningfully to actual deployment contexts. Third, interdisciplinary literacy is an important challenge to conducting research on robot ethics effectively. This workshop can help dismantle communication barriers that arise due in part to difficulties posed by differences in framing and vocabulary in research originating from different disciplines. Fourth, by creating an accessible environment for researchers new to the field of ethical AI and robotics, this workshop promotes learning for those just entering the discipline.

This workshop presents several invited talks and discussion panels designed to stimulate conversation and interdisciplinary communication. Invited talks from researchers with considerable experience conducting applied research and panels that focus on identifying important near-term objectives provide a clear picture of where the field of ethical robotics stands with respect to its goals. Through offering these invited talks and panels, along with the opportunity for contributors to present novel research, this workshop will help researchers appreciate the nuance and connectedness of many problems in ethical AI while identifying gaps in our knowledge and opportunities for new research.

Schedule

8:30 - 9:00 AM
Breakfast
9:00 - 9:15 AM
Introduction and Setting the Workshop Agenda
9:15 - 10:00 AM
Opening Remarks
  • The impact of AI and robotics on the future of work: Using AI to empower and enable participation in the job market (Shlomo Zilberstein)
  • The organization of knowledge production: Who designs emerging technologies and how can they be imagined in equitable ways? (Laurel Smith-Doerr)
  • Driving and Automation: Stakeholder interests and how automated vehicles will change the driving landscape (Shannon Roberts)
  • Intersectionality of Race, Gender, and Skill: Historical labor market vulnerability and who gets replaced when technology advances (Anna Branch)
  • The New Spatial Mismatch: Examining the intersecting geographies of industry, skill, and race in an AI-transformed economy (Henry Renski)
10:00 - 10:30 AM
Coffee Break
10:30 - 12:00 PM
Interactive Roundtables to Identify Research Gaps
  • AI and the Future of Work (Yellow Table led by Shlomo Zilberstein)
  • Knowledge Production (Purple Table led by Laurel Smith-Doerr)
  • Driving and Automation (Green Table led by Shannon Roberts)
  • Intersectionality of Race, Gender, and Skill (Blue Table led by Anna Branch)
  • The New Spatial Mismatch (Red Table led by Henry Renski)

  • Captivating Technology: Reimagining Race, Innovation, and Equity in Everyday Life
